references.R07LAU01USGP: Laudenslayer, Jr., William F. and Monica D. Parisi. 2007.  Species Notes for Oak Titmouse (Baelophus inornatus): California Wildlife Habitat Relationships (CWHR) System Level II Model Prototype. California Department of Fish and Game.
references.B00CIC01USGP: Cicero, Carla. 2000. Oak Titmouse (Baeolophus inornatus), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu.ezproxy.spl.org:2048/bna/species/485b
references.W09NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2009. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer. (Accessed: March, 2010 ).

habitat_description: The Oak Titmouse is closely related to the Juniper Titmouse and was considered the same species (Plains Titmouse) until recently.  Typical habitats are warm, dry oak and oak-pine woodlands with openly spaced oak trees with a grassy understory, such as blue-oak woodlands, coastal oak woodland, valley oak woodland, and blue oak foothill pine (Cicero 2000 and Laudeslayer, Jr. and Parisi 2007).  Shrub habitats including scrub oaks are used when adjacent to woodlands (Cicero 2000).  Other warm, dry plant communities that are free of oaks are used as well:  “western juniper (Juniperus occidentalis) woodland in extreme n. California, open pine forests (digger pine [Pinus sabiniana], Coulter pine [P. coulteri], Jeffrey pine [P. jeffreyi]) on San Benito Mtn. in central California, single-leaf piñon (P. monophylla) or California juniper (J. californicus) mixed with Joshua trees (Yucca brevifolia) at eastern limits of range in Kern, San Bernardino, and Riverside Cos., CA. (Cicero 2000),” chamis-redshank chaparral, closed-cone pine-cypress, deciduous orchard, eucalyptus, mixed chapparal, montane hardwood, montane hardwood-conifer, urban, and valley foothill riparian.  Reported elevation ranges are 12 - 1,981 m in the Upper Sonoran Zone, and up to 2,194 m in southern Baja California (Cicero 2000).  N. Tarr, 11Oct2012.
